section.h2: Top played tracks from the last month

section.div: Favorites genres: Action, Comedy, Fantasy, Drama, Romance

div.div:
A strange turn of events leads the Dragon, Tohru, to work as Miss Kobayashi's maid. She occasionally (that's a lie, she often) causes trouble for her beloved Miss Kobayashi while blending into human society and splendidly (that's a lie, only mediocrely) carrying out her maid duties. Her fellow dragons, Kanna, Lucoa, Fafnir, and Elma all find their own places to fit in as well and enjoy interspecies interactions with the humans. Yet while they're all enjoying that laid-back and occasionally turbulent left, the threat of a new Dragon swoops down upon Miss Kobayashi.
(Source: Crunchyroll)
Action, Adventure, Drama, Fantasy, Horror, Psychological, Thriller

The second season of Yakusoku no Neverland. Fifteen children escape Grace Field House, a false paradise, hoping for a chance at freedom. Instead, they encounter plants and animals they have never before seen, and are chased by demons. The outside world is so beautiful, and yet is almost too cruel to face. Even so, the children refuse to give up. They are guided in their search for better lives only by a message from Minerva and a pen Norman left behind in order to fulfill their promise to return to the House to save those of their family who are still trapped within.
(Source: Aniplex of America) Note: Episode 1 streamed early on Amazon Prime on Jan 7, 2021. The regular TV broadcast started on Jan 8, 2021.
Shingeki no Eroko-san: Hen na Oneesan wa Danshikousei to Nakayoku Naritai

Shindou Eroko is a 27-year-old NEET whos made a popular persona for herself as a horny, big-breasted woman online. When her glasses are on, shes in business mode. But the moment her glasses come off? Its lewd Eroko-san. Unfortunately for her, shes totally out of cash. Taking a job as a handyman, she immediately finds trouble in the form of high schooler, Hoshi-kun. Hes totally her type, and as of right now, her glasses have just fallen off...

(Source: Comikey) Note: Takes place after volume 14 of Henjo: Hen na Joshi Kousei Amaguri Senko.

IS ONE REALLY THE LONELIEST NUMBER?
Haruka is just your average high school loner, minding his own business and keeping to himself as he makes it through his high school career, until one dayhe's suddenly sent to another world alongside the rest of his class!
Before he knows it, hes face-to-face with the god of this new world, who presents him with a list of cheat skills to choose frombut theres a catch. Its first come first served, and his classmates have already beaten him to the punch.
Haruka has to make do with what he can get as he navigates his way through this brave new world, all while flying solo!
(Source: Kaiten Books)
How do you use Aeron MDS with multiple publishers and a single subscriber where the publishers are unaware of the subscriber machine IPs?

I am trying to use Aeron Multi-Destination-Subscriptions where I have multiple publishers publish messages to their own IP address and port. I want a subscriber to subscribe to each of the publishers IP addresses and PORTs on the same stream ID. The publishers and subscribers are on separate machines. For simplicity, I'm testing this with a single Publisher and Subscriber setup. I am using docker to create a virtual network so I can designate the IPs of the publisher and subscriber machines. Here is my example code: Publication code final String publicationChannel = new ChannelUriStringBuilder() .media(UDP_MEDIA) (3 more lines were trimmed) Subscription code final String subscriptionChannel = new ChannelUriStringBuilder() .media(UDP_MEDIA) (8 more lines were trimmed) I have a doWork in both of these which repeatedly call subscription.isConnected() and publication.isConnected(). I expected this to work just like the MDC example where you can use control-mode=manual on the publication side and call publication.addDestination(subscriberIP:port) where the subscription would be setup to subscribe to its own subscriberIP:port. In testing, the publication and subscription are not connected. This test class in the aeron repo uses MDS over UDP using localhost and using multicast addresses MDSTest so I thought the same would hold true for using the publisher machines IP and port. Would really appreciate if someone could explain why this doesn't work?
